results.title: Animation on 4. Vol. 01
results.creator_credit: Channel Four, Lee Stork, Barnaby Spurrier and James Bradley
results.brief_description: Seven examples of the recent renaissance in British animation fostered by Channel Four. “Next” (dir. Barry Purves) elegantly condenses all 37 of Shakespeare’s plays into 5 minutes. “Feet of song” (dir. Erica Russell) is an abstract explosion of African dance rhythms. “The Victor” (dir. Animation City) uses comic book graphics for its dissection of chemical manipulation of military aggression. “Early bird” (dir Aardman Animations) is a witty claymation sound collage of a radio station at work. “Girl’s night out” (dir. Joanna Quinn) is a raucous comedy where a bored Welsh housewife is transformed during a bawdy night at the pub. “Deadsy” combines David Anderson’s animation with Russel Hoban’s narrative on the arms race. Finally, “The Black dog” (dir. Alison De Vere) is a wry imaginative fantasy on female sexuality.

results.title: Animation legend Winsor McCay
results.creator_credit: Lumivision Corporation, La Cinematheque Quebecoise Montreal (Quebec) Canada, Albert Miller and Winsor McCay
results.brief_description: All ten of Winsor McCay’s films and fragments are on this compilation, transferred from the archive prints at Cinematheque Quebecoise. An important figure in the development of cinema, he developed a stage act at the beginning of this century that incorporated a series of “lightning sketches”, which in turn led to his creation of moving pictures.

results.title: Animation in the school classroom
results.creator_credit: Alex Milsky Productions and Alexander Milsky
results.brief_description: A very detailed film showing students and teachers how animation is possible with a minimum of equipment. It gives advice on what paper to use, methods of production, importance of teamwork, advantages of experiment, how to make a light box, how to make an animation table and the requirements of the camera. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Animation greats!
results.brief_description: A compilation from the National Film Board of Canada spanning 20 years with eight short animation works using a variety of animation techniques. “Special delivery”: Winner of the 1979 Academy Award for Best Animated Short this animation is about Alice and Ralph Phelps and their battle to solve the mystery of the dead mailman - a comic moral tale. “Getting started”: An animation about procrastination as our hero attempts to practice on the piano but is constantly distracted. “The Big Snit”: This award winning wacky film looks at two simultaneous conficts, the macrocosm of global nuclear war and the microcosm of a domestic quarrel and how each is resolved. “Get a job”: Follow the tribulations of a cartoon character, Bob Dog, as he hunts for a job. “The Cat came back”: Based on a century old folk song, Mr Johnson becomes increasingly manic as he tries and tries again to rid himself of a little yellow cat. “Juke Bar”: A Juke Box is deliverd to a cafe and the cockroaches that infest the place jump and jive all night inside the ‘Juke Bar’ only to become trapped and removed in the morning. “Blackfly”: A folk tune from 1949 about the prevalence of the black fly in northern Ontario brought to life through animation. “The Lump”: Using a fun technique of recycled objects and photos of people’s heads, this is the story of George; who although short and ugly, develops a lump on his head that has handsome human features which he uses for political gain - until corruption catches up with him. Some titles also available on VHS or 16mm [012927], [014401], [017344], [316221], [301087].

results.title: Animation from Cape Dorset
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Sikusilarmiut, Joansie Salamonie and John Taylor
results.brief_description: This film is a collection of short animated sequences produced by Eskimos of the Cape Dorset (Baffin Island) Film Animation Workshop. This was established to teach to northern people a new and novel form of creative expression. There is some explanation in English and some in Inuktitut.

results.title: Animated women
results.brief_description: Five very short films made by women give us glimpses of aspects of the lives of some women. The films include: 1. “The Ballad of Lucy Jordan” by Ian Moo Young. Music by Dr Hook and The Medicine Show (stills and animation) 2. “Later that night” by Barbara Bottner. Music by Phillip Namanworth (animation) 3. “Brews and potions” by Deborah Healy. Music by Valentino Brothers (animation) 4. “Made for each other” by Barbara Bottner. Music by Phillip Namanworth. 5. “A la votre” by Monique Renault. Music by Rene Koenig.

results.title: Animated stories
results.creator_credit: Australian Children's Television Foundation and Patricia Edgar
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Lift off”.
These animated stories from the television series “Lift Off”, written by leading Australian children’s authors such as Paul Jennings and Jean Hepworth, open up a new world of fantasy and imagination for children. This collection of ten short films displays the work of some of Australia’s most talented animators. The titles included are “Snookle”, “Hunting the not fair”, “Rough, rough”, “Jason becomes a giant”, “Molly’s sock”, “Ice flowers”, “Murgatroyd’s garden”, “Dancing pants”, “Fair swap” and “Burping baby”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Children’s Television Foundation and Patricia Edgar
